    0 Intro

    https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/441872141

    1 Backtesting architecture - backtesing.py

    documentation: https://kernc.github.io/backtesting.py/doc/backtesting/backtesting.html#gsc.tab=0

    2 Evaluation of Backtest

    1. exposure time [%]: The percentage of time that the strategy is in the market with an active position.
    2. Equity Final
    3. Equity Peak
    4. Return [%]:The total percentage return generated by the strategy during the evaluation period. "The strategy grew the initial quity by x%."

    %\text{Return} = \frac{\text{Final Equity} - \text{Initial Equity}}{\text{Initial Equity}} \times 100%

    1. Buy & Hold Return [%]: The return you would have earned by simply buying and holding the underlying asset throughout the evaluation period.
    2. Return (Ann.) [%]: The annualized return
    3. Volatility (Ann.) [%]: The annualized volatility of returns, representing the riskiness of the strategy.

    Volatility=252Ã—ÏƒdailyÂ returns \text{Volatility} = \sqrt{252} \times \sigma_{\text{daily returns}} Volatility=252â€‹Ã—ÏƒdailyÂ returnsâ€‹

    1. Sharpe Ratio: A risk-adjusted performance metric that indicates how much excess return you earn for the extra risk taken, compared to a risk-free investment.
    • A high Sharpe Ratio suggests that the investment offers good returns for the amount of risk taken. It is a preferred metric for comparing the performance of different investments.
    • High SR investments are typically favored for constructing efficient portfolios.

    SharpeÂ Ratio=Rpâˆ’RfÏƒp \text{Sharpe Ratio} = \frac{R_p - R_f}{\sigma_p} SharpeÂ Ratio=Ïƒpâ€‹Rpâ€‹âˆ’Rfâ€‹â€‹

    Rp:Â portfolioÂ return R_p \text{: portfolio return} Rpâ€‹:Â portfolioÂ return

    Rf:Â risk-freeÂ rate R_f \text{: risk-free rate} Rfâ€‹:Â risk-freeÂ rate

    Ïƒp:Â volatilityÂ ofÂ theÂ portfolioÂ (standardÂ deviationÂ ofÂ returns) \sigma_p \text{: volatility of the portfolio (standard deviation of returns)} Ïƒpâ€‹:Â volatilityÂ ofÂ theÂ portfolioÂ (standardÂ deviationÂ ofÂ returns)

    1. Sortino Ratio:Similar to the Sharpe Ratio but only considers downside risk (negative volatility).

    SortinoÂ Ratio=Rpâˆ’RfÏƒdownside \text{Sortino Ratio} = \frac{R_p - R_f}{\sigma_{\text{downside}}} SortinoÂ Ratio=Ïƒdownsideâ€‹Rpâ€‹âˆ’Rfâ€‹â€‹

    Ïƒdownside:Â standardÂ deviationÂ ofÂ onlyÂ negativeÂ returns \sigma_\text{downside} \text{: standard deviation of only negative returns} Ïƒdownsideâ€‹:Â standardÂ deviationÂ ofÂ onlyÂ negativeÂ returns

    1. Calmar Ratio: Compares the annualized return with the maximum drawdown.

    CalmarÂ Ratio=RannMaxÂ Drawdown \text{Calmar Ratio} = \frac{R_{\text{ann}}}{\text{Max Drawdown}} CalmarÂ Ratio=MaxÂ DrawdownRannâ€‹â€‹

    1. Max. Drawdown [%]: The largest percentage drop from the peak equity value to a subsequent low during the evaluation period. A high MDD signals higher risk, indicating that the investment has experienced significant drawdowns. This can be a red flag for risk-averse investors. Worst-case senarios.

    MaxÂ Drawdown=PeakÂ Equityâˆ’TroughÂ EquityPeakÂ EquityÃ—100 \text{Max Drawdown} = \frac{\text{Peak Equity} - \text{Trough Equity}}{\text{Peak Equity}} \times 100% MaxÂ Drawdown=PeakÂ EquityPeakÂ Equityâˆ’TroughÂ Equityâ€‹Ã—100

    1. Avg. Drawdown [%]: The average percentage drop from the peaks to the troughs during the evaluation period.

    Avg.Â Drawdown=âˆ‘i=1nDrawdownin \text{Avg. Drawdown} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \text{Drawdown}_i}{n} Avg.Â Drawdown=nâˆ‘i=1nâ€‹Drawdowniâ€‹â€‹

    n:Â #drawdowns n \text{: \#drawdowns} n:Â #drawdowns

    1. Max. Drawdown Duration: The maximum time in days that the portfolio took to recover from a drawdown.
    2. Avg. Drawdown Duration: The average duration (in days) the portfolio was in a drawdown state.
    3. # Trades: The total number of trades made by the strategy during the evaluation period
    4. Win Rate [%]: The percentage of trades that were profitable. A win rate of 64.86% means that about 65% of the trades made money.
    5. Best Trade [%]: The largest percentage gain on a single trade.
    6. Worst Trade [%]: The largest percentage loss on a single trade.
    7. Avg. Trade [%]: The average percentage return per trade.
    8. Max. Trade Duration: The longest time a single trade was held (in days).
    9. Avg. Trade Duration: The average number of days that trades were held.
    10. Profit Factor: The ratio of gross profits (æ¯›åˆ©) to gross losses (æ€»æŸå¤±). A value of 5.51 means the strategy's gross profits were 5.51 times higher than its gross losses.
    11. Expectancy [%]: The expected return per trade. Here, the strategy has an expectancy of 2.79%, meaning that on average, each trade is expected to return 2.79%.

    Expectancy=(PwÃ—Aw)âˆ’(PlÃ—Al) \text{Expectancy} = \left( P_w \times A_w \right) - \left( P_l \times A_l \right) Expectancy=(Pwâ€‹Ã—Awâ€‹)âˆ’(Plâ€‹Ã—Alâ€‹)

    Pw:Â probabilityÂ ofÂ aÂ win P_w \text{: probability of a win} Pwâ€‹:Â probabilityÂ ofÂ aÂ win

    Aw:Â averageÂ win A_w \text{: average win} Awâ€‹:Â averageÂ win

    Pl:Â probabilityÂ ofÂ aÂ loss P_l \text{: probability of a loss} Plâ€‹:Â probabilityÂ ofÂ aÂ loss

    Al:Â averageÂ loss A_l \text{: average loss} Alâ€‹:Â averageÂ loss

    1. SQN (System Quality Number):evaluates the strategy based on both its risk and reward. A value of 2.9 indicates a fairly good trading system (a value above 2 is generally considered good).

    SQN=RË‰ÏƒRÃ—n \text{SQN} = \frac{\bar{R}}{\sigma_R} \times \sqrt{n} SQN=ÏƒRâ€‹RË‰â€‹Ã—nâ€‹

    RË‰:Â averageÂ tradeÂ return \bar{R}\text{: average trade return} RË‰:Â averageÂ tradeÂ return

    ÏƒR:Â stdÂ ofÂ tradeÂ return \sigma_R\text{: std of trade return} ÏƒRâ€‹:Â stdÂ ofÂ tradeÂ return

    n:#trades n: \#trades n:#trades
